content: I think you misunderstand the purpose of native design standards. The intent is to create familiar experiences that are easy to use. The purpose is not to be a creative buzz-kill, but to help your grandma order a pizza, or your younger brother play an education game. Using a familiar look and feel lowers the learning curve. Users will expect things in certain places and creating a new interface for every single app creates new learning curves. As a designer, you can trust Google’s rationale as long as it actually works and makes sense! When it comes to UX, there’s no need to reinvent the wheel on a premise of being ‘creative’. Could google’s framework allow for more customization than font and color? Probably :)
